caseStudies.title: An Unexpected Diagnosis
caseStudies.scenario: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and a persistent cough. She is a non-smoker with no significant past medical history. A chest X-ray reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe.
caseStudies.question: What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Obtain a CT scan of the chest
Reassure the patient and repeat X-ray in 6 months
caseStudies.explanation: A CT scan is crucial for better characterization of the nodule (size, borders, calcification) and to guide further investigation, such as a biopsy, if warranted. While a biopsy may eventually be needed, CT is the standard next step.

caseStudies.title: A Young Patient with Joint Pain
caseStudies.scenario: A 22-year-old female presents with a 2-week history of migratory polyarthritis, a low-grade fever, and a new skin rash. On examination, you note a malar (butterfly) rash on her face and swollen, tender joints in her hands and knees.
caseStudies.question: Which autoantibody is most specific for the suspected diagnosis?
caseStudies.explanation: The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). While ANA is sensitive for SLE, Anti-dsDNA is highly specific and is part of the diagnostic criteria.
